nexttext: with $P_{MKS}=\int IdX$ the beam power per unit length in the transverse $Y$ direction and $k=2\pi n_0/\lambda$ the wavenumber. In a nonlocal medium the refractive index variation $\Delta n$ can be written as

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="2ik\frac{\partial A}{\partial Z}+\frac{\partial^{2}A}{\partial X^{2}}+2k^{2}%
\frac{\Delta n[|A|^{2}](X)}{n_{0}}A=0," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mo>∂</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msup><mi>X</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
The function $G$ is proportional to the Green function and it is normalized such that $\int GdX=1$. We observe that Eq.~(\ref{Dn}) originates from the solution of the Fourier heat equation for thermal nonlocal nonlinearity.\cite{Gentilini2013a}\\
We write Eq.~(\ref{nls}) in terms of the normalized variables $x=X/W_0$ and $z=Z/Z_d$ with $Z_d=kW_0^2$
prevtext: with $P_{MKS}=\int IdX$ the beam power per unit length in the transverse $Y$ direction and $k=2\pi n_0/\lambda$ the wavenumber. In a nonlocal medium the refractive index variation $\Delta n$ can be written as
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta n[I](X)=n_{2}\int G(X-X^{\prime})I(X^{\prime})dX^{\prime}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>I</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>X</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>I</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>X</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msup><mi>X</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\psi=AW_0/\sqrt{P_{MKS}}$, with $\Braket{\psi|\psi}=1$ denoting Hilbert space scalar product. $P$ is set as $P_{MKS}/P_{REF}$, with $P_{REF}=\lambda^2/4\pi^2n_0|n_2|$. $n_2$ is the nonlinear optical coefficient and $K(x)=W_0G(xW_0)$ is the nonlocality kernel function.


\noindent As shown in \cite{Gentilini2015}, in a highly nonlocal medium, i.e. when the nonlocality function width is much wider than the field intensity and the highly nonlocal approximation (HNA) is valid $[K(x)\ast|\psi|^2\simeq\kappa(x)]$, the solution of Eq.~(\ref{nls2}) is strongly linked to the eigenstates of a RHO. These states are the so called Gamow vectors, firstly introduced by Gamow in $1920$s in nuclear physics in order to describe particle decays and resonances. \cite{gamow1928quathenucdis} It can be shown that GVs can be obtained by extending the harmonic oscillator eigenfunctions in the complex plane:\cite{Chruscinski2004}

We write Eq.~(\ref{nls}) in terms of the normalized variables $x=X/W_0$ and $z=Z/Z_d$ with $Z_d=kW_0^2$

nexttext: where $H_n(x)$ are the $n$-order Hermite polynomials. The $\mathfrak{f}_n^{\pm}$ are discrete states belonging to a rigged Hilbert space (RHS) $\mathcal{H}^{\times}$, which is an extension of the standard Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$. In $\mathcal{H}^{\times}$ the Khalfin theorem \cite{Khalfin57} does not hold true and exponentially decaying wavefunctions are admitted. Indeed, the eigenvalues of the RHO Hamiltonian

In $\mathcal{H}^{\times}$ the Khalfin theorem \cite{Khalfin57} does not hold true and exponentially decaying wavefunctions are admitted. Indeed, the eigenvalues of the RHO Hamiltonian

nexttext: The eigenfunctions $\phi$ can be expanded in terms of Gamow eigenvectors as

where $\psi(x,0)$ is the initial physical state and $\Gamma_n=\gamma(2n+1)$ are the GVs quantized decay rates. \\

RHO Gamow eigenstates have the peculiar characteristic of being the eigenvectors of Fourier transform operator. Indeed, one can observe that the reversed oscillator eigenvalue equation has the same form as its Fourier transform within a phase factor. Considering the RHO Hamiltonian in the position basis ($\hat x \rightarrow x$ and $\hat p \rightarrow -i\partial_x$) we have:

RHO Gamow eigenstates have the peculiar characteristic of being the eigenvectors of Fourier transform operator. Indeed, one can observe that the reversed oscillator eigenvalue equation has the same form as its Fourier transform within a phase factor. Considering the RHO Hamiltonian in the position basis ($\hat x \rightarrow x$ and $\hat p \rightarrow -i\partial_x$) we have:

nexttext: where rect$_W(x)=0$ for $|x|>W$ and rect$_W(x)=1$ for $|x|<W$, which is the range of the spatial confinement. During evolution each Gamow component in Eq.~(\ref{gs}) exponential decay with rate $\Gamma_n$: the ground state has the lowest decay rate $\Gamma_0=\gamma$ and higher order Gamow states decay faster than the fundamental one. This allows to consider only the fundamental GV in the far field. We compute the Fourier transform $\mathcal{F}$ of the fundamental state of Eq.~(\ref{WGV}):
prevtext: To describe the far field with this formalism, we cannot neglect that GVs have an infinite support. Hence, to account for the spatial confinement of the experiment, we introduce the windowed Gamow vectors:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\phi^{W}_{G}(x)=\sum_{n=0}^{N}\sqrt{\Gamma_{n}}\mathfrak{f}^{-}_{n}%
\lx@Braket@V{\mathfrak{f}^{+}_{n}}{\psi(x,0)}\mbox{rect}_{W}(x)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>W</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover><mrow><msqrt><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>𝔣</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msubsup><mi>𝔣</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo></msubsup></mpadded><mo rspace="4.2pt">|</mo><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mtext>rect</mtext><mi>W</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: where rect$_W(x)=0$ for $|x|>W$ and rect$_W(x)=1$ for $|x|<W$, which is the range of the spatial confinement. During evolution each Gamow component in Eq.~(\ref{gs}) exponential decay with rate $\Gamma_n$: the ground state has the lowest decay rate $\Gamma_0=\gamma$ and higher order Gamow states decay faster than the fundamental one. This allows to consider only the fundamental GV in the far field. We compute the Fourier transform $\mathcal{F}$ of the fundamental state of Eq.~(\ref{WGV}):
